abstract.para: Comparison of arctic grayling growth in fertilized and unfertilized sections of the Kuparuk River, at high and low fish density.

intellectualRights.para: Acceptance and utilization of LTER data requires that:

listitem.para: The Principal Investigator be sent a notice stating reasons for acquiring any data and a description of the publication intentions.
The Principal Investigator of the data set be sent a copy of the report or manuscript prior to submission and be adequately cited in any resultant publications
A copy of any resultant publications should be sent to:Principal Investigator Ecosystems Center Marine Biological Laboratory Woods Hole, MA 02543

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Kuparuk River. CONTROL ZONES: High density, -0.8K to -0.9K; Low density, -0.9K to -1.3K; Ambient density, -1.3K to -1.8K. FERTILIZED ZONES: High density, 4.1k to 4.0K; Low density, 4.0K to 3.2K; Ambient density, 3.2K to 2.7K.

description.para:
For Archival Use:
DATE RECEIVED: DATA FILE ENTERED BY: DATA FILE VALIDATION: NAME: DATE:

para.literalLayout: The response of fish to fertilization was determined by monitoring adult grayling from control and fertilized river reaches. In early July, four fish weirs were constructed in each zone. Adult fish in each section were weighed, measured, tagged and released. Fish densities were manipulated in each segment so that there was one section with ambient (10 fish per km) density and one section with high (50 fish per km) density. In August, tagged fish were recaptured to measure growth of individual fish.

Notes: Many D/D and RECAPD/D locations are estimated, because notes were kept regarding zones fish were captured in, not specific locations. Unless a specific location was given, the following estimates were used: HDC, D/D=-0.8K; LDC, D/D=-1; ADC, D/D=-1.5K; Control Zone, D/D=-0.1; HDF, D/D=4.0; LDF, D/D=3.6; ADF, D/D=3.0. On 4 August, 1988, flooding of the river resulted in most of the weirs being overtopped. Recapture length and weight measurements are not available for fish which escaped at this time.
